They get little tears in them while working out (or just the daily grind) and the foods you eat (amino acids-protein) help to build them back up and repair them :) Does that help you?  Here is a more scientific def:  After you workout, your body repairs or replaces damaged muscle fibers through a cellular process where it fuses muscle fibers together to form new muscle protein strands or myofibrils. These repaired myofibrils increase in thickness and number to create muscle hypertrophy (growth).  Building (hypertrophy) is specific to reps/sets/and weight choice as well. Just so you know :)
A decrease of cytosolic Ca makes them let go of troponin.

+Samira Ali Protein is made at ribosomes. Protein makes up a lot of useful bits (hormones, enzymes etc..). All cells need protein as they all need these bits. I don't think muscle cells have particularly more ribosomes than other cells, so the protein is probably just for your basic maintenance stuff (e.g. the myofilaments are made up protein so it would be manufactured to replace damaged myofilaments). As for why they're multinucliated, that's just because they're made up of smaller cells fused together, so it's the nuclei from all these cells that you're seeing.

To control of release of calcium. An action potential moving down a t-tubule causes a receptor (DHP) to open a channel (RyR) in the sarcoplasmic reticulum (inside the cell) which causes the release of calcium. The SR stores calcium until the action potential triggers the opening of the channel.

Science

Because if our fist is clenched to the point where we feel we're applying force,  we are applying force. Applying force against what? Two things (at least), against the resistance of the opposing muscles and connective tissue to being stretched (their elasticity), and also against the elasticity of our palm, which we are jamming our fingers into as we clench our fist. Usually also gravity, in some way, but in exactly what way depends on our current orientation in space. In some scenarios, I imagine it could reduce the amount of force we need to clench our fist. Muscles produce force when they contract initially, but they produce no more force in the desired direction once they are contracted. So, how could we produce the continual force we feel when we clench our fist? It requires rapidly relaxing and contracting the muscles so as to repeatedly produce force in the desired direction. Hence, continuous(ish) use of energy.

Lactic acid is produced, and that's why you're sore after exercise.

1. ATP binds to myosin, this makes myosin release itself from actin.  2. ATP broken into ADP and P to release energy. This energy is stored (think of it like... cocking a gun).  3. P (phosphate) is released from the myosin. This is what provides the "kick" for it to move forward to cling onto the next section of actin. Known as "power-stroke". Energy from breaking up ATP is released. 4. ADP is released.  Sorry... Limited by the no. of characters I'm allowed. But those are the steps :)

As explained by Hank, your muscle needs ATP to work. Tons of it.  When you stress out a muscle (especially with sudden intensive exercise, or a lack of oxygen), lactate builds up. Lactate acid is, well, acid, and the low pH it brings about inhibits certain enzymes involved with the metabolism of glucose into ATP. If the pH of your muscle drops to far (to acidic) the muscle will not be able to regenerate it's ATP sufficiently. As Hank explained, without ATP your muscles cannot relax

We do build muscle all the time, but, like all cellular tissues capable of rebuilding themselves, muscles rebuild at a faster rate when damaged.  Working out stresses and destroys muscle, prompting the rebuilding process.  Because the stresses create a mostly even distribution of damaged sites, the new structure is often more efficient than the old structure.  Also this means the way you work out is more important than how much you work out. Working wrong can destroy muscle without any benefit.

Because the way the sarcomeres work (when you're alive) is by rapidly contracting and relaxing.  This is because the neuron signal can't be constant (because of the way action potentials work). So it's more like a strobe light.  And every time the signal reaches a sarcomere, it contracts, but as soon as the signal leaves, it relaxes.  So the muscle contracts and relaxes like a strobe light too.  This doesn't happen when you're dead because you run out of ATP and no relaxation is possible.

The "chronic" overcompensation of the muscle leads to modification of its structure, size and (to some extent) its own physiology. A bodybuilder's "guns" are completely different from a weightlifter's ones: the first's are prepared for VERY short-term moderate weightlifting, which gives the muscle its "inflated" appearance. The weightlifter's "guns" are adapted to medium-term heavy weightlifting, rendering its appearance "not as ripped" as the bodybuilder's ones.

What you are calling 'exercise' the muscle perceives as 'trauma'. The muscle is adapted to make certain movements with a limited amount of weight in its insertion. When you overload the muscle, it will be damaged. As a response to that trauma, the muscle overcompensates (to protect itself) so that, if such trauma ever occurs again, it won't be as badly damaged as the first time.

It's because on this small scale within a cell everything is so close together and well... small.  None of the atoms have to move very far. Now think of how small a cell is in comparison, what, like a million times smaller?  So atoms only have to move about a millionth of the distance, so things happen a million times faster!

Muscles only 'want' to be in a tensed state because they are constantly primed (at least while you're alive) with potential energy ready to cause contraction. The 'contracted state' is the lower energy state (less potential energy, therefore more stable) only because the resting state has so much stored potential energy.

In the event that a muscle goes long periods without contracting (for arguments sake, as one's muscles would in a coma) what happens to the ADP and the phosphate that's hanging out on the head of the myosin strand?

It's not that the energy is 'used' when the ATP is binds to myosin, it is converted into potential energy (PE). ADP bound myosin has PE which it can released, by binding to actin, once Ca2+ ions cause dissociation of troponin. The ATP then 'recharges' the muscle cell, by pumping out Ca2+ and binding to myosin heads, leading to dissociation from actin. It doesnt take energy to relax, but muscle cells must store energy before they can do work. Succinylcholine - its' mechanism demonstrates this.

Its basically the same answer for both questions---whenever you work your muscles (or impact your bones) even lightly, you get hundreds of tiny little microscopic tears in muscle fibers, and the crystal-string-looking nanostructures that make up your bones. Every tiny little tear gets repaired stronger and denser than it originally was. . And you get sore because those torn muscle fibers stimulate a release of lactic acid, which, when built up in torn up muscles, aches like a bitch.
